description:
One of my favorite places to come to in the Castro. Perfect for a first date, a professional meeting, or just pulling up your laptop and doing some work. I've had so many great conversations here with baristas and guests alike, it kind of feels like home.

AMBIANCE is warm. The lighting is a bit on the darker side, but the brown tones and space makes the spot feel friendly. I like to sit at the front seats facing the window to take in the daylight.

ORDERED previously: matcha iced tea fog, matcha latte, earl grey frappe, coffee. 

DRINKS are great. They use ceremonial-grade matcha for their matcha drinks, and they have no issues switching regular milk for almond milk when I'm ordering a dairy drink. 

OVERALL four stars. A great spot to visit to get some caffeine and conversation.
author: Nicholas G.

description:
Good chain coffee shop in the Castro. Clientele is very gay. Great place to get work done, people watch, or meet a friend. No oven here so they don't offer breakfast sandwiches or hot pastries. 

This location was recently renovated with nomes seating and more cold food/drink options. Staff is friendly. Ask for a bathroom key. 

This location can't seem to keep the store clean. You usually have to bus and wipe your own tables, the floor is dirty, door has finger prints, and the condiment bar has dried stains. Good luck trying to identify pastries as they are hardly ever labeled.
author: Alan H.

description:
Peet's I love you.  I've been going here for ages.  Today was a disaster.  There were 4 homeless people camped out in your store and you didn't even know or do anything about it.

A guy was asking for change in line while we waited.  Another was passed out in a chair.  There was one guy who was there with all his bags and letting his drool fall on the table and a woman who's hygiene was horrible.  

I know homeless is a big problem in our city but if you don't do something about it you are going to lose your faithful customers.  

Ick ick ick.
author: Michael D.

description:
Good coffee, mostly the medium roast but in a pinch the others will do. They always have a line out the door and the pastries are decent so I think it's a good, safe choice when in the city. 

The only problem I have ever had there (and it's not really that big a problem) is sometimes you order a roast and then find out they just ran out and need to brew a pot. When you're in a rush that is a pain. I would rather order something else and get moving. But like I said, no big deal. 

The staff is friendly and keeps the line moving which is all you can ask for when you're in the city and trying to move on to your next location. Always warm and toasty inside, I love it.
author: Adri L.

description: I don't even know why I try here.  They can't blend a Matcha green tea to save their  lives.  The last 2 times (yesterday being one of them) I bought this drink they are to busy to blend it properly so you get CHUNKS OF ICE IN THE DRINK !!!  Come on guys !!!! It's impossible to drink with chunks of ice getting stuck in the straw and to thick to drink as if it's one chunk ... Don't punish people and not give customers what they pay for because you are to "busy".  If so then take the efin blended drinks off your menu !!!!!  So frustrating!
author: Jack O.

description:
Our biggest decision was where to eat lunch on our last day in the city.  The air was nippy and Peet's, which I've never been to, was right across the street from our hotel in the Castro.  So, we popped in to discuss this important issue over a cup of joe. 

ATMOSPHERE:
It's a good sized coffee shop with a few tables and high tops inside and out.  

MENU:
Coffee, juice, scones, muffins. 

BEVERAGE:
Mocha - Being that I'm not usually a hot beverage drinker, I opted for the small size with whipped cream.  It was way too sweet which overpowered any creaminess and coffee flavors that a good cup of mocha brings.  I'm not sure what happened but the whipped cream looked like a child had squirted it on.  I drank 1/4 of it before tossing it.  Thankfully my drink was paid for by a friend's donated coupon of some kind so it was no loss to me.  

SERVICE:
The female barista was friendly, and beverage service was fast.  Another female associate was passing out free samples of banana bread which were good. 

OVERALL:
Overly sweet mocha.  Head to Castro Coffee Company for a better cup.
author: Vince N.

description:
I love Peet's coffee. Just picked up 3lbs of Major Dickason's. That's my favorite blend. 
The staff here  is excellent. So friendly and funny. 
Thanks, Victor for great service and also for grinding up one pound of my coffee. 
Can't wait to make a brew!
Right now I'm sipping a tasty latte while Yelping. 
Good service makes such a difference.  
Keep it up guys.
author: Thomas D.

description:
The price is worth it for great tasting coffee. I ordered a Vanilla Latte for myself and a White Mocha for my friend. We were both pleased with our coffees. The shop itself was pretty nice, very spacious compared to a lot of smaller Peet's locations. 

I found a couple mugs that were "on sale" on the shelf and decided to purchase one since I'm a bit of a coffee cup collector. I took it to the counter and the woman working was extremely friendly, she even gave me an extra percentage off. Excellent customer service.
author: Ashley A.

description: This is the best Peets in the bay area. Best window seating, best service, nicest people working there. I come here as often as possible because they remember my name and always make me feel welcome.
author: Angela W.

description: These people really need to get their app working. This is the tech hub of the country.
author: Jon C.

description: I don't know what is going on at Peet's in the Castro but the service has been extremely slow on my last few visits.  Also lots of mistakes with orders and expresso drinks.
author: Tom T.

description: The rudest coffee shop I have ever been to! We were three young girls from out of towns, lost, our phones had all died and we were trying to find our way back home. We went into Peet's to charge up just long enough to get us an Uber home. We walked in and asked the guy who was closing if we could charge up for just 10 minutes and buy a drink, we just needed long enough to get us directions home from our phones. His response was "actually I do have a problem with that, we will be closing in 15 minutes and need to start deep cleaning so actually you will be in the way." I have never had anyone respond so rudely, and we only needed a place to charge our phones and we had no problem buying drinks.
author: McKenna M.

description: Just walked in, and out, of the store on Market Street in the Castro. Got up to the counter when the person cleaning up said, no, YELLED out "We're Closed!". Is that how YOU would wish to be greeted when entering a store?  So we had 10 minutes left. WTF! He needs some re-training or should find another line of work! I HATE this Peet's. Listen. You are not doing me a favor by being open. There are a plethora of other more customer-oriented options in the Castro.
author: Larry N.

description:
I've always been a fan of this Peet's location. It's very spacious and with plenty of tables and seating. Iced tea or iced coffee are both my drinks at Peets. You'll find a much older crowd here, at least that's what i noticed on my last visit here. The staff are very friendly and they're usually very quick in getting your drinks out to you asap. I guess a downside of the place is that they only have one restroom. If there are a few people that need to use it, you'll see a line forming along the ramp in the back. 

Oh..and their WiFi is pretty good. It's not spotty or slow like other Peet's locations.
author: Andrew S.

description:
This is literally one of the worst Peet's that I've ever been to. The only reason that I even come here is because it's convenient after going to the gym.

 The first time I came here, I ordered a COCONUT BLACK TIE WITH LIGHT ICE! The guy goes and makes my drink in front of me filling the entire cup with ice, and then he proceeds to fill up my drink. When he handed it to me, I already felt how heavy it was and after literally 3 sips, my drink was literally half gone with a lot of ice showing. Since I needed my coffee dose, I had to go to another Peet's located on 16th to get me a new drink!

I decided to give this place another chance considering that I don't usually say "shit" about any restaurant or anything without giving them a second chance because it might have just been an off day. Oh boy was I wrong. Ordered the same drink coconut black tie with light ice PLEASE! Drink literally was all ice. God dam! Do you not understand what light ice means !???? Whatever.

Then I've got to thinking, maybe I should try to get a drink without ice

So today, I went and ordered a MEDIUM sugar free vanilla latte with soy milk and a chocolate croissant. Not surprisingly, the lady made me a SMALL sugar free vanilla latte with soy milk. I told her politely that I think I ordered a MEDIUM. She proceeds to get a MEDIUM cup and pours the SMALL into the MEDIUM CUP in front of me and then hands it to me! ARE YOU FORREAL B**ch! I paid for a MEDIUM not a small. I didn't want to make a big deal out of it in front of everyone, so I just left. But that was just the last straw. It's not even about the money that I'm mad about. It's the way she just poured the small into a MEDIUM expecting that to be okay and without even giving two fucks. On top of that, it wasn't even that busy there. So many people making drinks without even a rush or a line. Is it that hard to make me a new one or add a little bit more to my drink. 

Never coming to this Peet's location again! Trust me, I love Peet's and get it everyday but not this one. Just gonna say this! Go to a different location!
author: Shirley G.

description: Great coffee, mostly dark roast that I love. Have been going to various Peet's since visiting in '69 & moving to SF, then Walnut Creek. Today Christmas Eve I went into to this Peet's with my App open to get my free coffee however the cool counter person told me to save it. Free coffee for everyone this day!
author: Joshua C.

description:
Was at the nearby Davies and had an urge for some coffee from Peet's. Checked on Yelp and found that the closest one was this Peet's on Market three blocks away. 

The front of the store had a lot of tables with a view of busy Market St.  People were on their laptops or reading newspapers. To order your drinks, the counter was at the back of the store.  There was no waiting line at all and I got my coffee and was on my way.

This Peet's was a nice and mellow. For my next visit to Davies, I'll be back to this Peet's to get my cup of joe.
author: Al L.

description: So SAD... This has been such a nice quiet place to have a conversation over coffee or read, now they are making it more like a bar with huge speakers and loud music.  Coffee shops are for conversation and reading.  If i wanted to hear that pounding bass, I would go to a bar.
author: Jeff Y.

description:
Rather than "Peet's Coffee," I think the shop should be renamed "Typhoid Mary's Coffee."

For two days in a row, this coffee spot failed to have soap in their bathroom. 

I actually bought them 5 bottles of hand soap the first day. They either ran out or just didn't feel like putting the soap out for their customers. 

After finding no soap on the second day, I pointed out the issue again, but one employee in particular didn't care much about the problem. He said that people handle cash, and that's dirty; so it doesn't really matter that people can't wash their hands after getting fecal matter on them. 

I can only imagine that there are all sorts of dangerous bacteria spread around that store and our community now. 

Their disregard for the health of their customers, neighbors, and fellow employees is deplorable and unacceptable, and I'm sure the health inspectors and corporate will find this all very interesting.
author: Brandon M.

description: Peets is a pretty consistently good chain if you're not looking for hipster, offbeat coffee, and this location is not exception. The service was really friendly, and I had no problem find a nice place to sit an work. It was a little drafty but I happened to be there on a day that was really cold and rainy so I think I was a little extra sensitive to the temperature. It's a good location and seemed pretty busy, but not busy enough that the crowds would keep me away. The people behind the counter were also happy to chat and make recommendations. It wasn't the cleanest coffee shop I've ever been in (crumbs and the table was a little sticky) but I think it's hard to keep that busy of a coffee shop spotlessly clean anyways.
author: Jenny C.

description:
I will say, i am a fan of Starbucks, but i gave this a shot. Tried the Fog Cutter latte, it was really good. It was a unusual coffee with a cinnamon twist. The foam on the latte was thick and perfect. I wished i could have another one right now. 

I would like to visit again and try their brewed coffee. But i will say it's one great place for coffee.
author: Jim C.

description: This Peet's has undergone significant upgrades in terms of staff friendliness, cleanliness, and Wi-Fi consistency.  You get the same Peet's coffee, but now you get a sleeve and lid for your hot coffee w/o having to beg.
author: David S.

description:
They have a new crew here. Haven't been back in a while so decided to try it again. Everyone is friendly and the baristas are doing a way better job.

It's expedient and the drinks are good. I think I'm going to start making this peets a regular part of my routine again. They've one me back. Hope it keeps up as I've been disappointed in this one in the past. However, so far so good.
author: Chris D.

description: a rip off-- it used to be better -- the pieces of cake used to be so big and affordable-- now after they renovated the store, it is empty and the pieces of cake are so small and so expensive-  garbage and thieves-- i went once and right out the door when i saw corporate America ripping off people
author: Marbi F.

description:
The service at this location has dropped recently.

I have to assume there's a new manager (and there has been turnover in the morning crew), which has resulted in a big drop in service and attitude.  Before, as with the other Peets that I frequent, the barristas really make you feel like they are happy you're there.  This morning, after being the only person waiting to order, someone finally took my order.  The woman acted as if I was pulling her away from more important duties by making her take my order.  Really too bad.
author: David M.

description: This is a wonderful place to get your coffee! Especially if you don't like Starbucks. If coffee is as important to you as it is to me you should come here. So good. And really lovely people.
author: Zepha O.

description:
Needs a clean-up.  Increased prices are NOT justified.  Coffee is OK - any baked goods
are STALE - DRY.
author: Richard D.

description: The coffee is very good at this location. The wait to order is not good. The line was very long when we entered. There is a weird counter in the middle of the building where it appeared to be just for grinding beans? The food selection is pastries and desserts. Although I did not have any, they did look good. The dark brew coffee was amazing, hot and fresh! The prices are average as well. They have a variety of finishes for the coffee and it did come out quickly.
author: Big D.

description:
This team is amazing! Sparks my day! 

It's usually clean and service is always kind and welcoming.
author: R B.

description: The service was very quick when I was there.  I got a chai tea latte, but was disappointed when it ended up being a little bit too foamy.
author: Maranda W.

description:
I stop by Peet's in the morning since I work in the Castro and it gets the day going. I've always felt like Peet's was too strong for me so I try to get half-caf, which still feels like it's your normal caffeinated cup of coffee. (Don't ask me why I like coffee when I can't handle caffeine!!)

I think the layout of this particular Peet's is weird since there are two areas with cash registers, but you walk in and go straight to the back to order your coffee. Not sure what the first little cash register area is for. Buying coffee beans? I don't know. Usually a medium sized line on most weekday mornings. And yes, most of the people sitting inside sipping coffee are men... with handsome beards. I'm always tempted to just sit among them and eavesdrop on their fantastic conversations. Anyway...

Lots of cute doggies and puppies outside waiting for their dads to finish their coffee dates. So cute.

I think the staff is usually friendly, not perky friendly but nice enough. Definitely think the store could use a layout change. It doesn't feel very feng shui...

The free wifi is spotty and there is never enough space for me to sit near a power outlet.

All in all, I'm there almost every morning for some coffee, albeit maybe it'll be decaf next time because I cannot keep getting so anxious off a simple white mocha. Oy.
author: Peggy C.

description:
The staff @ this Peets are very friendly and very fast. It's my regular weekday morning coffee stop! Several of them have been working there for at least a couple of years now, which I usually take as a good sign.  Most of them remember what I always order, which is great.

There are usually a lot of folks camped out in the front area, and often a line waiting for coffee, but the line always moves extremely quickly.
author: alex j.

description:
I have been here only twice.  The first time was in the middle of a weekday, so I felt that I was quite possibly the only woman there... The second was on a Saturday, so I blended in with all the female tourists.  Fortunately for me, I had good service on both occasions.  There are always cute dogs waiting outside Peets.   

Try the new matcha green tea!  

Wish I had thought to use the Yelp app to get $1 off...  Oh well, there will be a next time, since Peet's is very nice to have a Yelp promotion often.

Yes, you might see a nude man wearing nothing but a hat gettin' his caffeine fix here.  I did briefly think about the chair I was sitting on and the chance it once seated bare buns and balls.  But there's a higher chance of that happening on the public seating by the muni.  Only in Castro!
author: Miran C.

description:
Peet's is not my usual stop for coffee in the Castro BUT, I do come here if nothing is open very early in the morning on weekends. The latte used to be better. For some reasons their coffee roast/espresso has got weaker over the years. The lattes now have this terrible foam. The last two visits my lattes weren't piping hot even though I requested for them to be. Is this because Peet's has "starbucked" itself? 

Also I notice they will up-sell you when you get a cup of coffee. If I want a pastry, I'll order one so no thank you, don't ask me every time. Sometimes they would even ask if I need a gift card. What outrageous effrontery!

Now the real issues for me---enough to turn me away from this location, is their filthy storefront. It's filthy and disgusting. It's beyond my brain why people would even want to sit on the benches outside. Poor doggies who had to sit out and tolerate all that filth.

There are better choices out there since Castro is no longer the coffee wasteland it used to be. Illy, Four Barrel coffee, Blue Bottle, Reveille---all have settled down in the neighborhood. I deserve better coffee and better services.
author: Matt Y.

description:
AMAZING service! I usually don't drink Peets, but Knick, Harp, and all the other employees will keep me coming back. They were all smiles and laughs; made my day. Thank you guys for your outstanding service!

Once again, I had the opportunity to visit this Peet's' location again with my therapy baby Rocky. I just love the friendly outgoing staff here. Thank you guys for making me feel at home!!!
author: melissa g.

description: Peet's is great in their coffees and delicious muffins cookies, sandwiches but gets a two star rating for two reasons first in their lack of effective Wi-Fi. When one thinks of a coffee shop one thinks of doing school work, reading New York Times, getting on any Wi-Fi Device which is usually everything, but Peet's seems to be lacking in this department.
author: Zack T.

description:
Stopped into this Peets with my to-go cup to grab some coffee on the run for my first bit of the day. I'd already put some creamer into the cup from home and have never had a problem with that before until now. 

The barista rinsed the cup without asking anything, then dumped it, saying "Sorry. Did you want that? I just always rinse before." When I told him that was creamer I wanted from home, he said he could add milk. I was incredulous and pissed, so I just left. 
If they carried a decent French vanilla creamer that would have been okay, but they have nothing like that. And I wasn't gonna spend more money to get a latte because he was clueless, careless, and treated our interaction more like an inconvenience than anything else. 

I don't plan on going back anytime soon after that. It's just coffee, but it's not cheap. No business should be careless with a customer's money if they want repeat business.
Sign me an ex-customer at this Peets.
author: Kevin W.

description:
This is Peet's store is perhaps the only coffee shop that looks like an old school coffee shop and not a college library (e.g. people doing homework). Internet is slow or has poor signal. 

Maasala tea bags is the BEST chai. High quality, aromatic, fresh ingredients, no sugars or flavorings added.

Regular coffee is strong for a regular stomach. 

Some baristas are friendly. Straight male baristas usually have attitude (it's the Castro!...they likely are hit by guys a lot).

Watch out the bathroom. They usually close it when you really need it.

SUMMARY: good place for  odd people watching, have a quality strongly caffeinated drink or just to grab the day's paper people leave in the recycling.
author: Emir A.

description:
Goodbye Old Peet's. You had to go and sell yourself. 

Hello New Peet's -- different staff everyday, apparently without thumbs. Long lines, slow "service", condiments always out. One might think a coffee place would have a stockpile of coffee stirrers and never run out. Not here, for days on end.  I hear the new owner's strategy is "sell more". I don't need to be asked if I want a pastry every time I order a cup of coffee. If I wanted a pastry I would have ordered one. Good luck on the "more income" bit -- with such slow service I would imagine the income barely trickles in. 

Goodbye New Peet's. It's not me, it's you.
author: gary c.

description: Quite place to stay, cappuccino with caramel flavor  is my favorite!
author: Weijian L.

description:
I saw the review from the person who commented on his experience as a straight man in a predominantly gay hangout and it brought back memories of the times I've been in this Peet's store. Yes, the minute you touch that door handle, you get scoped by the people who take up the stools by the front windows. 

Who knows what scenarios get played out behind those hard stares. I'm just here to get a cup of coffee, but I sometimes get a little unnerved when some of these guys follow me with those looks of hard judgement. 

Look, I understand that it's your neighborhood and I'm not a regular here. Usually I'm coming from Aardvark Books or Books Inc. Maybe a simple smile and not a look of disdain (or is it boredom)? 

By contrast, the guys (many who could be gay, bi or just curious) at the Pilsner Inn are great to be around. Is this just the difference between caffeine and alcohol? I'm just observing, and not proposing any scientific thesis.
author: Noe B.

description: I go to this Peets a lot as it is near my current office. They have some of the best middle-aged gay men people watching in the castro. The staff is all SUPER nice. They have my gluten-free morning glory muffins & let me add more chocolate sauce to my Javiva. Javiva beats Frappacino, btw. Thanks guys.
author: Shannon R.

description:
This place is a damn mess.  I went here twice before I decided to make final judgement.

The customer service is ok, but the lady with the short hair that works there has a stressed out "I'm in pain" look to her face.  One of the issues I have with this place is they ask you for your name, but then never write it on the cup or say it once your drink is ready.  Someone actually took my drink because I didn't know that my drink was ready.  I ended up waiting like 10 minutes for my white chocolate mocha.  Then they gave me a cold coffee when I wanted the hot one and she tried to charge me for it!  I told her it wasn't what I ordered and I wasn't going to pay for a replacement.  I don't know if she is on drugs or what because she wanted to charge me, then she said she would do it for free and then reverted back to asking me for money.  She finally pulled it together and I got the drink I wanted.

Well, once I drank the coffee, I was very underwhelmed with the lack of flavor.  It was like drinking hot water.  There was no flavor and the coffee didn't provide me with a boost.

The second time I went there I figured it would be best to order a hot chocolate because the coffee wasn't cutting it.  This too was also very underwhelming and had no flavor.

I don't know if the staff is just incompetent or on drugs because all I ever got was hot water.  AVOID THIS PLACE!  AVOID!  AVOID!  AVOID!
author: Shaun W.

description: they are the best coffee shop ever in san francisco. I totally adore them!
author: Maria C.

description:
I'm not a coffee snob. As a matter of fact, I'm not even really one who pays attention. Unless it's really bad or really good, I'm just not bothered. I'm just looking for a quick buzz to get me moving, I don't really care about the finer points of coffee appreciation.

That being said, this was one of the better lattes I've had... so I'd call it a four-star experience from someone who knows virtually nothing about coffee.
author: Sean B.

description: It was a great change from the usual Starbucks today. It's a little strange that the front counter and cash register is hardly used, but I guess the walk to the back is exercise. Gotta work for that drink. Loved the jasmine lime iced tea on this warm SF day (crazy, right? Thanks Global Warming!). I always go back. You should too. People are just calmer than Starbucks, and I need that reminder every now and then.
author: Denise H.

description: My fav cafe in SF, and I love that they offer free Wifi w/o code, BUT it was sooooo slow it defeated the purpose of doing work here. Seriously, it was like modem dial up speed when it took 5 mins for the page to load. I love the friendly baristas here and permanent coffee smell that wafts outside, even after they close. If you're trying to find a seat, come after 2-3p.
author: Thomas L.

description: Internet sucks.  Parked car, paid parking, risked life crossing street, ordered drink and hummingbird bread (damn good) and managed to find a table.  Discovered wireless was abysmal.  The manager really needs to hustle their a## and get the wireless working.  That's pretty much why I sit in a coffee shop and spend spend spend.   Not here unless it's fixed fixed fixed!
author: Jeff W.

description: Love the friendly neighborhood atmosphere of this Peet's, and the wonderful staff who know my name and favorite drink and always greet me with a smile. I love the tradition of walking to Peet's on a weekend morning first thing to start my day.
author: Andrew K.

description: This Peets location is great for Upper Market window shopping and a post-brunch caffeine fix. While their regular menu may offer standard coffee fare, their seasonal flavors are worth getting excited about. This past winter they offered "Winter Solstice," their spicy vanilla holiday tea blend, which it should be noted is secular does not perpetuate religious dogma (aka Starbucks "Christmas Blend"). This spring they have the Mint Matcha, which is delicate and delicious.
author: Marie F.

description: Jeebus the wifi here is slooow. It's painful! Friendly staff but terrible for actually doing  any work.
author: Adam R.

description:
Just another coffee shop?  Maybe.  But the folks behind the counter are genuine, the vibe relaxed, coffee is good and the price is right.  It's what keeps me coming back when I need a quick pick-me-up in the morning.

I'm not sure what it is but I think the lattes coming out of this shop taste better than other Peets locations and certainly better than Sbux.  And I don't get a side-serving of pretense with my order like some of the snootier places in the Mission.

Glad to have this in my hood and so close to the gym.
author: Cliff C.

description: Very well designed, with a very friendly staff. And, located near everything. I had a pot of Russian Caravan tea, and they were very generous with the hot water.
author: Dave S.

description:
I love Peet's. If I'm in unfamiliar San Francisco territory and need my token shot of rocket fuel, I'm pleased to see these beauties dotted about. The coffee is strong enough for my liking and this particular branch in the Castro gave us our perfect post-sandwich pick-me-up - the staff were friendly and hugely apologetic about any wait or inconvenience during Pride Weekend.

Seeing a Peet's in an American city to me is like seeing a Pret in the UK... you get fab ones and meh ones, but I'm pleased to say this one fell into the former category. Peet's is neat!
author: Emma Louise M.

description:
First things' first, I really do enjoy Peet's coffee.  Simply just not a fan of this location.  service is way too slow, and totally inattentive.  condiments aren't always available/well stocked, and often times (4x out of the 5 visit to this location), the place could you use a bit of a house cleaning.

so again, love the coffee, just not the service here.
author: Mike S.

description: Alas, this Peet's is not what it was. When we went in to buy a pound of whole beans the other day, we were offered the usual free coffee. As usual we declined and were given a discount coupon instead. That would have been dandy, but the coupon was not only dog-eared but filthy as well. When I complained, I was told that it would work as well as a clean one! The time before, when I ordered a small cappuccino, I had to leave before it was ready. There was no line. I had what I thought was ample time--10 minutes left on the parking meter. Problem was, the barista opted to take other orders--and complete them--before she turned to mine. I do hope things turn around. This is the Peet's closest to us and we really do like their coffee.
author: m n.

description:
Ok...I decided to write a review about this Peet's location specifically because of the awful employees.  As I read the other reviews, I see that many others share my opinion.  I love Peet's and I visit several other locations around the Bay Area where everyone is actually nice to me.  The employees at the Castro location on Market are the worst.  They act like I am interrupting their day when I order coffee.  Maybe they have a bad manager because these people are very unhappy for some reason.  I hope their corporate office reads these posts.

Peet's coffee deserves 4 stars in my book.  The employees at this location deserve 1 star, and that's only because they actually show up to work.
author: Shane C.

description: I've tried them all, but this is near the tippy-top of my go-to places for coffee. Employees are courteous and professional every time. And, of course, I love the coffee.
author: Jim H.

description:
I reviewed this place in 2010. Nothing has gotten better. This place has been going downhill for a long time. A flithy restroom where often the only toilet paper is rolling around on the floor, crappy wi-fi, long waits to buy beans because management no longer allows an employee to be stationed there, and mediocre hard product. The soap dispenser is a little plastic pump bottle, because they  decided to give up keeping a working soap dispenser attached to the wall. They no longer even stock paper towels, relying instead on an electric dryer, because they found it too inconvenient to stock paper towels. Now you have to grab your shirttail or your sleeve to open the restroom door after your hands are clean.

But the crowning glory is a new manager who has no ability to speak in anything less than a yell. I went in today and she barked at me to give her my refillable cup. She then barked at the cashier to charge me for something I had not ordered. I lowered my own voice and told her that she didn't have to yell at me, because I was right there, and no, I did not want the nonfat decaf latte with extra foam, or whatever it was. Later, when she had some time on her hands, she complained loudly--again, her only vocal setting--to her employee that she hates it when she tries to be nice and "people get defensive." When I asked her if she was referring to me, she claimed that she was talking about an employee. The notion that talking about anybody that way, especially while standing in a customer service area, was completely unfathomable to her. 

I'm a long-term customer of Peet's, but I've had it. I like a lot of the employees, and I know some of them well enough to know they hate the conditions their company makes them work under, and the continuing decline in the level of service they're able to provide. It's important to remember that there are still locally-owned alternatives in the neighborhood, where the management doesn't yell or think you should have to pick up toilet paper off the floor.
author: Paul Q.

description: This Peet's feels very warm & poorly air conditioned. The Coffee Bean Station in the entrance makes Absolutely no SENSE, Common Sense would suggest having the Barists up front, the layout is incredibly confusing & there are no bathrooms which takes this Peets down to 2 dismal stars
author: Julian I.

description: You know I love Peet's and all but I get such a bad vibe when I come in here in the mornings and sometimes during lunch. They never say good morning to you and they sorta treat it like, "order your shit and go" and I've been here at least a few times this week alone. The only person that has been friendly and personal with your order has been a lady that makes your coffee/drink. The few times she's taken my order, she's been the only cool person there (I don't know her name). She remembers my drink, personalizes my drink by saying my name--you know, friendly shit.
author: Lily W.

description:
First things first. I love coffee and have an incredibly open mind to what "good" coffee is.

Peet's Coffee is just that. It's good coffee. In fact, as I write this, I am enjoying one of the best tasting cappuccinos I've had in quite some time. I have nothing against Peet's coffee. He makes a great espresso drink and a decent cup of brewed coffee.

My beef is with this particular location's customer service. 

Here is what I experienced the last three times I have visited this Peet's over last few months.

Walk to the bar to place my order. No baristas are at either of the particular ordering stations. I hover between the two, receiving no attempts at service. All three times I have had to call out to get their attention, the baristas are too deep into their personal conversation to pay attention to the bar. And for whatever reason, each of these times, they have made a deal out of the fact that I am not at the "right" ordering station. There are two registers with no one at them, how is someone supposed to know which one to go to? Stay at your station and it will make things easier.

One thing I am particular about is my cappuccino. I want it to be a free-poured, light cup of foam with two shots of espresso at the bottom. Too many coffee shops either scoop foam into a cup (this closer to a macchiato than a cappuccino) or they put in the two shots, pour in some steamed milk and then scoop foam on top of that (this is a crappy latte, not a cappuccino).

A proper cappuccino has shots on the bottom topped with fresh steamed milk, made for that particular drink, not leftovers. The foam should be rich and thick, not too wet, not too dry. 

So my first time I asked how they made their cappuccino. They said exactly what I wanted to hear. Yay! I began to remark at how happy I was to hear that and that so many shops don't care enough to make cappuccino the right way.

Then they make my drink by pouring pre-steamed milk into my cup and then scooping foam from another pail of milk. My cappuccino is heavy and the foam on top is cold while the rest of the drink is hot. Gross. But not as bad as the customer service was.

The second and third time I went, my cappuccino was quite perfect but the customer service was the same or worse. No eye contact, no personalization of service. It reminds me of the kind of service you get at a post office during the Christmas rush.

I feel like the baristas there see themselves as superior to their customers. It's not a good experience. I worked at a coffee shop for six years and prided myself in providing happy, friendly and quick service every time, doing my best to match even the most bizarre orders to spec.

I live a block from this Peet's and yet I still find myself walking all the way to the Mission every morning to Four Barrel Coffee where the service is as great as their coffee.
author: Justin S.

description:
Delicious coffees & teas in relaxed atmosphere playing soft classical music .
Gay presence; eye-candy!!!
author: Christian Olsen S.

description: Great first stop here, I figured it's a chain so I didn't expect too much,  but I was pleasantly surprised.  Clean,  quick,  and darn good coffee.   Kind of busy, but I waited 10 minutes and soon a seat opened up.
author: Chris A.

description:
Good ol' Peets. Quick, easy feels like Sunday morning, everyday. Plenty of seats and tables to enjoy your coffee or tea, read a book, catch up on email, watch people, etc. Convenient location on Market, some people on the rush double park their cars in front. Not a good idea but they do it anyway. Must be the coffee. Buzzz.

There's a couple of benches in front of the cafe - a favorite hangout for people who bring their pooches along with them, or to catch the uber elusive San Francisco sun and warm weather.
author: Errol F.

description:
Wow, I'm surprised that this location has such a high score. I can't remember going to get a coffee at a place where staff ignored me and gave me such attitude as this one.

One star for making the coffee like rocket fuel.
author: Andy A.

description: Once I sat in on Friday night. The atmosphere and the couch is comfy. The coffee is def good.
author: Brandy C.

description:
I love Peet's and also love that there are more Peet's in San Francisco than Starbuck's.  Unfortunately, I have to drive way out of my way to find one in San Diego.  
This particular shop was fairly large for San Francisco and the people working there were super friendly.  I'll go back next time I'm in the area.
author: Tim R.

description:
Another checkpoint for my mission to visit all the Peet's in SF.  This would be #2, and it only took me, what, a year?  Hey, it's a life project.

This Peet's is quite different from the weekend neighborhood gab-spot in West Portal.  It has a little more age and wood-paneled stateliness (and a dedicated bean-buying counter!) that make it look like the coffeehouse for a fine hotel, or the professorial coffee bar at a fashionable college.  Which makes it the perfect prelude to a workday.  Grab your latte and a pumpkin bread, listen to the baroque string quartets coming from the speakers, and enjoy your morning imperturbability (or complacency, depending on how you look at it) while it lasts, Smithers-Jones style.  You know, while all your tasks for the day seem to be neatly lined up and waiting to be checked off.  Then after work, when everything has gone wrong, you can grab a much needed cocktail across the street at Cafe Flore.
author: Wes M.

description: Peet's coffee is delicious, and the folks at the Market location are always super friendly.  This specific location seems to be a super-social spot, so there is always great people watching or opportunities to make new friends.
author: Jack A.

description:
It's gooooood.

Get a coffee.
author: Cynthia B.

description: Peets coffee is the best in San Francisco, that cannot be said for the service at this particular Peets.  On the evening I visited to get a coffee, the cashier was having a long conversation with a patron.  The conversation continued for 5 minutes while the rest of us in line waited and our coffee got cold. He seem more interested in cruising with the customer instead of serving us. If there are people waiting in line, I think our purchases are just as important as his conversation about his neighborhood.
author: Eric M.

description:
Nothing wrong with the product, and most Peet's experience we've had were fine. But the service we got tonight was dreadful. We stood near the cashier who never looked at us, just off in the distance. Maybe burned out from a long day, but that's no excuse for hostility. To get his attention I asked "Are you ready?" and he answered back, sarcastically, "Are YOU ready?" 

Enuf said. Won't be rushing back.
author: Marvin G.

description: Firstly I wanted to thanks to Kelly who made my latte best and also his kindness. This location is so friendly that I wish I can come more often even thought I live in downtown.
author: Winny L.

description:
I received an e-mail from the Peets corporate office asking me to send an e-mail to their I.T. department in regard to their wifi problems.  I'm not sure why the person e-mailing me from their corporate office doesn't do this.  There are plenty of others noting the poor or spotty wifi at this Peets location.  They just need to send someone out from their I.T. dept to analyze the situation and resolve it.

In the mean time I discovered Jumping Java which has a very strong wifi signal, good coffee, yummy bagels, friendly staff, and a good cliental.
author: John ..

description: I think this is the classy version of the Lookout patio ledge.
author: Jeremy G.

description:
why are there not more peet's near me? i was taking a mini vacation and stopped by a couple of peet's for my coffee and tea needs because i'm so over star bucks and this location was my favorite of the two i visited. they were quick and friendly, what more can i ask for? the jasmine-lime (or is is it lemon?) tea was really good and refreshing and gave me the energy needed to tour the city that day =). 

please peet's, bring more peet's down to my area. thanks in advance.

*just a note. on the survey part of my review when it asks if there's outdoor seating at this location i'm going to check yes because i enjoyed my tea on the 3-person bench outside.
author: Michael G.

description: One of the best coffees around bar none, however... 2 things: the Wi-Fi service ALWAYS sucks! They can't figure out climate control! No matter where you go. LA, SF.. I've been to multiple Peet's between these 2 cities and the Wi-Fi is always shoddy and/or simply doesn't work AND the place is either waaaaay too cold or waaaay too hot! This is not rocket science!  C'mon Peet's you can do better!
author: Miklos P.

description:
Remember that scene in "Mean Girls" when Janis and Damian take out the map of the high school cafeteria and differentiate between the ROTC guys, JV jocks, preps, Asian nerds, cool Asians, unfriendly black hotties, girls who eat their feelings, girls who don't eat, and sexually active band geeks?

I don't think I need one of those maps for this Peet's.

If you're looking for a diverse crowd, this probably isn't your destination of choice. The biggest diversity will come in the form of beard grooming (or no beard at all...gasp!) or brand of jeans. 

As for the coffee itself, Peet's is my mass-produced coffee chain of choice. Their vanilla lattes are one of my favorite around! But word to the wise: the gingerbread lattes are realllllly sweet. Don't say I didn't warn you. 

I do like the remodeling and how they placed the coffee accessory table farther away from the ordering counter. It used to be such a hassle to fight your way through the line to get your 2% organic soy lactate milk. Get outta my way, bitches!

I do like this Peet's, don't get me wrong. I just think everyone stares a lot.
author: Jared S.

description:
Do you wan to have GOOD MORNING??

PEETS CASTRO  on market will give you a COFFEE that will make your day!

5 starts not just the coffee because a great coffee shop will not be complete without THE ROCKSTAR STAFF! 

Thanks PEETS!
author: Aemar E.

description:
This may be a large chain, but they've got it down!  I'm a bit of a cappuccino snob, and I have rarely been disappointed here.  On top of that, the staff are all exceptional at remembering the names of their regular clientele, and the service always feels personal (even when they're busy).  

I am thrilled to have Peet's in our neighborhood - what a great team!
author: Bill S.

description:
Me: I'd like a medium nonfat sugar-free vanilla latte. 
Cashier: So that's a small latte. *pause* Did you say nonfat? 
Me: *puzzled look on face* Um, actually that was a medium nonfat sugar-free vanilla latte. 

This after she (and the rest of the staff) spent a ridiculous amount of time with someone who I'm sure was a regular. After even more waiting, I finally receive my latte as an afterthought from the barista who was too preoccupied yelling over my head to a familiar face in line. 

2 stars for the strong coffee and great location (especially on a sunny day). 

0 stars for the service! And this is not an isolated incident. It seems the staff only services the regulars and could care less about putting on a good face for others. Lame!
author: Vicente G.

description:
When I get enough time on my hands I will tell cyberspace and all who read here about the horrible, horrible experience due to a complete disregard for all parameters of customer service, that I had at Peet's Upper (2257) Market yesterday - Sunday, May 12th at approximately 1:30-1:35 in the afternoon, which involved not one or two but FOUR staff there.

Suffice it to say that it was the worst experience I've had with poor customer service since, well - years? Or ever. And it starts with the bad attitude of ONE employee, spread to two others who were basically standing around doing nothing, and comes to the "Shift Manger" who refused to make it right which is when I became, well - let's say quite angry. Very Angry.

In my experience, (and I have gone periodically to this location since they opened about 20 years ago), some of the people who work there, and SOME OF the shift managers, have always, since the store opened, had a bad attitude, not suited for work in customer service. My experience continues with my general observation of the 
cliquish atmosphere of the place, where, if you are not one of the people who goes in there frequently enough for the staff to know by sight, name or beverage preference, and are rather someone who pops in occasionally for a jolt of coffee, in ever so subtle but actually quite obvious ways, you will be made to feel unwelcome. 

What I will, in a later review, write about this establishment will be considerably longer that this paragraph, but still constrained by brevity. But it will be scathing which is what the experience, from me, the customer's point of view, calls for.

Suffice to also say that I have, for 23 years lived, slept, worked, ate and played in the very neighborhood where this establishment is located, and lived in the same apartment for the entire time. I live, about, I dunno, less than a half mile from where this Peet's location is? A twenty minute walk. 

Now, I know that people tend to be more motivated to write bad reviews of places than register their delight if things have gone swimmingly. But this was way too bad to let slide and obviously the ACTUAL store manager will be getting the forthcoming review, with all details of the staff involved, in his email inbox. Not to mention Corporate which I have already submitted the foregoing to
author: Jeremy I.

description: Trendy place like every other coffee shop. My bud Steve and I came in here after a hearty lunch and while I don't drink coffee, I liked the place. I'd definitely come back.
author: Joe V.

description: I can write a song about you guys! But I'll save u the heartache.
author: Tiger H.

description: There have since been many strides in my 'wecandoit' neighborhood store. The staff have leveled out with good contributors- there is the tall dirty-brown guy who seems asleep/stoned at all times, but...who knows. I notice the curlyguy surfer super-tan manager from chaos-days gone by is now gone (good- sorry to him though!!). Overall, Fernando is super nice and totally hooks me up everyday with my coffee- we don't have much to say, but we try- he is a nice guy just getting his job done. The rest of the staff also seem much more attentive, and the bar area seems less neglected. I know we have the potential to go 5 stars. For now, I am a happy customer and GLAD to patronize my hometown favorite (come on guys- let's make Castro the best!).
author: Chuck H.

description: I went in just wanting some tasty coffee creation and left with some dark chocolate mocha monster.  It was quite tasty and actually got tastier the more I drank it.  I tried telling myself to stop but I just had to finish it.  The guys working there were really nice and when my friend spilled her drink accidentally they replaced it for free.  I also really love buying the tins of teas from Peet's so if you like tea, they have a really great variety in addition to the Starbuck's like coffees.
author: Jess K.

description: Peets coffee is fine. It tastes good but I wouldn't say its great. I like some of the other stores but this location is just weird. I had only come here once or twice a year or more ago and was reminded the other day when I went there why I should never come again. I don't like having to walk down that dimly lit back alley like hallway to use the restroom. And I was disgusted by the three homeless people who were camping out in the store with all there trash bags and luggage making ramen noodles with hot water provided by the barista. The store needs to be updated or remodeled in my opinion but even so, it is not a homeless shelter. The two baristas didn't seem to care what was going on in the store. The overall setup of the shop is just strange anyway since they are so far away from the doors and where people sit. I know for certain that I will never go to this location again.
author: L. A.

description: Ah, the jasmine lime tea was too good :-)
author: Spring B.

description:
I think I got the crew that was a little off and mean today.
The cute boy at the cashier (glasses and fauxhawk) was laughing at our orders and smirking.  I politely asked for a medium soy latte... and he had a sinister smile..... The order guy standing there was just yelling, :anybody want grinded coffee" or something like that. weird. Our orders came.... Tatsuo order mocha with whipped cream, me my soy latte and Hiro a regular latte.  We have no idea which one is soy.... coffee girl points to it, but it don't taste like soy.  my friend drinks his, and he's like, it's soy..... but we still weren't sure.....  somehow I think I
ended up with regular milk cuz my stomach was starting to feel funky.
the crew was just weird and not friendly. location and other customers seem pretty cool though
author: Lita T.

description:
This review is unique, coming from someone who has both worked here and has been a customer on multiple occasions. The baristas that work at this location, including the asst manager and general manager, are wonderful and friendly people. This is a very fast-paced and stressful environment to work in, and the employees can potentially be short with someone if they approach the register with a terrible attitude. However, anyone who is half decent to the workers will be treated like gold.

My issue with this store is the abhorrent customer base that frequents it. People are disgustingly rude at all times. There will be a solid 5-6 hours of nonstop rush, all the while the cashier has to deal with the most horrifically mean-spirited old queens anyone has ever encountered. People rarely tip, rarely say thank you and hardly ever acknowledge a polite "good morning, how are you?" (the most common answer: LARGE LATTE!!!!). As if the disgusting excuse for humans that is the customer base at this location wasn't enough, this is just a bad company to work for. The benefits are completely not affordable (almost 100 bucks a month for the most bare bones excuse for "medical care" complete with a 35 dollar co-pay and deductible). The pay is minimum wage with a potential raise of up to 3% one time per year (that doesn't even match the city-mandated annual minimum wage increase). The corporate overlords are completely uncaring and let it be known that each and every employee is dispensable. 

Trash talking this sad excuse for a company, and the sad excuse for humans that are the average customers aside, the quality of drinks is just poor. Milk is supplied by Berkeley Farms (factory farmed garbage, think about that next time you pay four dollars for a latte) and all of the sauces are made with high fructose corn syrup. My suggestion: go somewhere else. Spike's and Philz are excellent alternatives and are conveniently around the corner.
author: L M.

description:
Let it be known throughout the land that a tiny, yet eye contact heavy interaction with one of the baristas here inspired me to post my very first missed connection (yeah, you'd think i'd be all up in that shit, right? nuh-uh) and that the object of my missed connection actually responded. No idea what will happen next, but it's a nice feeling to know that your instincts are not always completely off the mark, huh?

This particular Peet's is a classy respite from the HARDCORE gay cruising scene that is Bearbucks and is by far the best coffee in the Castro (after Castro Cheesery of course, I have not had Philz yet so I can't comment). And there are always adorable dogs hanging out outside.
author: Maria D.

description:
Dear Gay Peet's,

I love your gay location in the gay Castro with your gay baristas serving your gay coffee to your gay customers with their cute gay dogs. Your gay gingerbread latte after my gay dinner with my gay wife was perfect as we strolled gayly down the street.

Sincerely yours,
Anastasia B.
author: Anastasia B.

description:
i loves coffe.
i likes pretty men.
i likes to watch the pretty mens check out my boyfriend, whilst i drink the coffee i loves.
author: Susy C.

description: I miss Peet's so much-- we used to have them in Larry's Market (now out of business). I don't think y'all need me to tell you the coffee is good-- so just joining the choir with this review!
author: Janis H.

description:
This is a Peet's shout out. . .

I chose the Castro because this is closest to home.  Honestly though, all the people who work for Peet's are great.  

I used to hit Peet's on Montgomery Street when I worked downtown. . .like daily.  They all knew my name and order.  I love that.

Yo!  To all the Peet's in the Bay Area.  No matter what location, it's always consistent.  Great people, great coffee.

Cool people aside, if the coffee was not good, I would not give my business to Peet's.  

My favorites are Fair Trade Blend, Sulawesi-Kalosi, Sierra Dorado, and Espresso Forte.  Great full flavor, low acid so the belly doesn't freak the funk.

What I like best about Peet's is they're local, the founder is Dutch, and they are environmentally sound.  Again though, if the product wasn't good, none of that would matter to me. . .well except for the Dutch part.  ;  )

In all seriousness, Peet's does a lot for the local and global communities.  http://www.peets.com/who_we_are/community_technoserve.asp

Sometimes after drinking a cup or two of Peet's coffee, I can do amazing things like put together a huge IKEA wardrobe without instructions.  Now that is a miracle.  Thank you Peet's!
author: James M.

description:
I'm generally in a very sleepy/bitchy mood pre-morning-coffee. 

Therefore, I don't take well to being checked out or flirted with by strange men in coffee shops.

Problem solved!
author: Liz G.

description:
Pluses: good service, the usual Peet's array of vegan cookies, good soy latte.
Minuses: no soft seating, too breezy and cool, narrow long space.
author: Bob G.

description:
I love this Peet's.
The coffee is frothy, foamy perfection.
And they are so darn fast...according to their plaques on the walls, the fastest in the country...impressive!
author: S F.

description:
OH MY GOD SO MANY MEN!  SO MUCH SCENERY!  (too bad they want NOTHING to do with me)

and the coffee isn't bad either!
author: Katie H.

description:
Peet's on Market is hottie central.  Hot baristas, hot patrons, hot dogs.  Not hot dogs like the kind you eat, but you know, the dogs are hot.  There's always some adorable pup perched out front with its cute little come-hither doggie face and its tongue all falling out of its mouth.  A cute dog by your side will always get you laid, I say.

The coffee's not bad here (but I can not betray my beloved Blue Bottle, so Peet's only gets a still respectable 4 stars), but I'm going to take a wild guess and say that 80% of the patrons at Peet's are not there for the coffee.  They're there for a tall drink of somethin else.
author: Diana Y.

description: I like Peet's. It is what it is. But I give this one a low rating because their wifi sucks. Like, it's barely existent. Impossible to connect, and when you can, it's like 1997 slow. I realize coffee places should be rated for coffee and other things, but it's 2014. Get some normal wifi.
author: Cee D.

description:
A porn star took my boyfriend's seat.  I didn't mind per se... luckily a female friend was unaware of his status and was able to say "our friend is sitting there."

Is it the magic of the Castro?  or the magic of Peets?  or the perfect marriage of a neighborhood and great coffee?  Yes!  Whether you need to fuel up or people watch, Peet's fits the bill.

The baristas are always cool, friendly, and fun!  The coffee is always great and the pastries are always tempting!
author: Bradford S.

description:
Dark, hot, frothy, delicious caffeination.

Peet's makes Starbucks seem like dirty water.  The coffee is better, the store is cooler, even the design on the cups is hipper.

I have regained morning consciousness on many a morning at the Market Street location and it's always pleased me.  If it's an afternoon or evening jolt you're looking for and the tables are full (as they usually are) grab your cup and head next door to Books Inc.
author: Matt O.

description:
Baristas: I know as well as you that the food is industrially produced and not very delicious, but do you need to laugh in my face when I order a poppyseed muffin? And then make crunching noises and food commentary to each other while I pay? 

Coffee is always delicious.
author: Ivy S.

description: The baristas are fast and funny. I like that they have Chobani yogurt available. Peet's coffee is the bomb!
author: Lia B.

description:
Coffee is a little more about function than form for me, and when I need a good buzz to keep me going in the morning, nothing beats Peet's Sumatra. It's definitely rich and full bodied. A large cup with frightening amounts of cream and sugar and I'm chugging along for a good 8 hours.

This location is fun because it definitely feels part of the Castro. The staff look like they're having fun, and if you can snag a seat on a sunny day, it's fun to watch the parade of gayness go by.
author: Alberto V.

description:
I would not like to work here the way it is - but the people who do are always polite and cheerful. Kudos for that. And Peets coffee is probably the best of the chains - always a hard, round, and creamy latte! Great as an espresso, too! Coffee by the pound - go for Major Dickasens, if you like your coffee HARD, ROUND, and CREAMY!

What I don't understand about this place is the layout. The coffee bar is right at the back of the long, skinny store, where it is, frankly dark and gloomy. If I worked here it would get me down. And don't look out the window as you queue up - there is a nasty looking light well between buildings, that is neither light nor well. Whereas there is a perfectly good bar in the middle of the store where you can buy ground coffee, whole beans and such. Switching the whole thing around would be so much more pleasant, creating a cozy little grotto at the back for people to sit and drink. But, I guess that's just my opinion.

(That wasn't very amusing or clever was it? I really should be in a better mood when I write these things. I am still pissed at my dry cleaners! Grrr!)
author: Kingpin X.

description:
Where else can you go with clothes on from the night before, smelling of stale grey goose, get a much needed coffee buzz and get a sincere "ooh girl you look fabulous" all in one 5 minute ritualistic morning trip for java?
hated it.... NOT
loved it!
author: Jenny M.

description:
For a change, Peet's actually had drip coffee made and ready on Friday afternoon...I was surprised as it's usually not the case because the employees at this location seem to have plenty of time to chat with each other and their friends and mill around doing nothing, but very little time to pay attention to making coffee.  However, when an employee finished sweeping the floor and carrying/placing floor mats, and then served me (including running her hand around and into the coffee filter) without bothering to wash her hands, this Peet's lost a customer.  I left feeling gross and shocked that she needed to be told to wash her hands. 

On the plus side, I emailed Peet's through their web site and received an email response and a call from the store manager, with an offer of a free beverage.  Nothing, though, can take away the nasty memory I have of that experience.  Thanks, Peet's, but I'll take my coffee without health code violations...even if it means making it myself at home.
author: Glenn R.

description:
I love Peet's coffee... by far the strongest cup of brew I've had at any "chain" cafe.  When I worked in the city, I started my day with a short coffee (+cream, sugar, cinnamon),,, and that kept me turbo-charged at least until 3 p.m.  The scones are also pretty good... MUCH better than the sugar packed sugar dough mounds of sugared sugar at Starbucks (which is all I'm surrounded by now that I work in the Jo).  

BUT.  I de-star Peet's on the following two points (I really want to give Peet's 3.5 stars, but I chose 3 instead of 4 so that you might be more inclined to read this):

1. Aside from the nice man who used to hit on me at the Market & Battery location, in my experience the staff at any Peet's location is lukewarm at best.  They could learn a thing or two from the Howard Schultz School of Living La Vida Barista.

2. The low-fat Blueberry Banana muffin has TWO BLUEBERRIES!  See those two bluberries on the top of the muffin?  THAT's F&@$!%# IT!!!  TWO blueberries does not a "blueberry" muffin make!!  And the banana part will make you gag.
author: seema s.

description: marvin said service was slow when he was there and when i was there they were fast like they wear old fashioned roller skates with 4 metal wheels and a key used to tighten skate to shoes. yummy hot chocolate served with a smile warmed even my little right pinkie when drinking from huge mug, yum yum. i like this location for its convenience when i am in a hurry.
author: Sin D.

description: Coffee is delicious, I'll give them that. But what's up with the staff at pretty much every Peets I've been to. It's like they got all the cool people who enjoy what they do and hired them at Starbucks and got all the negative aloof people and hired them at Peets. I always leave feeling kinda mad and I'm not sure why.
author: Daniel K.

description: I come here for the coffee. As to other peoples reviews that there are friendy staff at times,  they also can be a bit indifferent in my opinion. Not the best place for quickcup of java, and beware that you need to dodge the darting child here and there. The catwalk to the counter is a morning ritual for many in the hood as well as the people who double park outside.
author: Joe R.

description: I find the staff at this location to be more concerned with talking to each other than getting orders right. It feels like they are doing you a favor by waiting on you.
author: Tony F.

description:
Best. Coffee. Ever. 

I miss my Peet's! When are you coming to Kansas City? This place needs a jolt. 

Oh, and I always liked the relaxed attitude of the baristas. Gimme a break, it's not fine dining.
author: Ken L.

description: I love this peet's location! They make the best soy lattes ever! Plus their bulk beans are a necessity considering how much coffee I drink a day and the employes are the best! super friendly and good looking!
author: Everrett T.

description:
As a noncoffee drinking, caffeine adverse type, you'd probably wonder why I would review this at all.  Well, it is called Pete's Coffee & TEA, see? They're teas are quite lovely and they have that impressive bar in the front where they will talk to you about tea and coffee purchases.

The staff can be eccentric at times, but are nice overall.
author: Sean S.

description: Best coffee for me in the morning. Packs a punch and gets me going. Staff is usually friendly has great banter going on that makes for a fun morning. Meet many of your friends in the perfect Castro stop.
author: Jim H.

description:
I really do love this place...totally...completely...utterly...

It's cozy, and inviting. The people there, in all my experiences, have been super friendly and chatty and nice. That's such a wonderful thing to find in a barista, as well as someone working in customer service, but more importantly...a character trait in a human being!

I love that I can be whoever I want. They never say, "Can I get your name?" for the drinks. They always ask me, "Can I get A name?" I've been Andrew Luster, Stewie Griffin, and once when I was completely silly I was, "That guy from that one 80's show."

And yes, they wrote that out (and called it) word for word. 

I love them! :)
author: Nicolas H.

description: 5 stars for a great staff. They move the lines quickly and their friendly sparkles help me on my day.  Special props to Barista Jillian for suggesting assam golden tip tea (sp? i'm forgetful). She was funny and eager to introduce my taste buds to something new.  Barista (Bryce?) was another helpful cutie.  ..I like adding people's job titles to their names...a habit I've kept since my Sesame Street days I suppose.  Whatever.  Check out this location if you're ever in the neighborhood.
author: kina a.

description: Great for using free wifi and checking out the hot gay men that wander through. Peet's coffee is always pretty good.
author: Rex D.

description:
I do not drink coffee like ever except for an occasional pick me up if I am on a bad one from a late night. I hate being on "bad ones".

I have in the past had a peet's coffee based drink, and all I remember is it being very strong coffee which is im assuming what coffee drinkers like and desire.


All coffee aside,let me tell you about my obsession.Hibiscus Tea Cooler. I always get the biggest size possible and guzzle it down .I never knew iced tea and splash of lemonade could be so amazingly refreshing. its a dream,A DREAM
author: Lauren V.

description:
It's the Starbucks of NYC in SF.
It was OK, nothing special. There are sooo many cafes and cute coffee places that aren't chains I'd skip it.
author: Joann P.

description: Stopped by today, Sunday afternoon, the barista was full of attitude and was acting like he just hated having to work on Sunday.
author: D M.

description:
I love Coffee, especially rich and delicious beans that feel like I had picked them myself.  I am giving this place an average as I was so disappointed with the amount of foam I paid for when I ordered my Mocha.  I ordered a large, and received about less than a small, with the remaining 3/4 cups filled with foam.  I never knew foam was so expensive.  I thought I bought a Mocha, not Foam with a dash of Mocha.

I still love Peet's (over all other chains) but, C'mon - do I need to really receive such a large amount of foam?  Can't we have a small amount, and request more foam if we want empty air...

Since I am on a banter, what is up with the cups/lids?  I thought I had a hole in my lip, but these cups suck. Always dripping.  Thought it was a fluke or rare experience, but it happens each and every time.  Ugh!!  I want to drink it, not wear it...
author: Benjamin B.

description:
It's Peet's - how can you go wrong? Best coffee chain - I love my LARGE (not Venti) Peet's coffee, strong and brewed to perfection. As a true coffee drinker, I rarely get the lattes and other stuff but a friend did buy me a Schafrenberger (sp?) Frappucino and it was delicious and gave me a nice buzz too! Much better than the froo-froo stuff from Starbucks. 

This is in the Castro so on a typical day, the boyz are spilling over onto the street but it's not too crazy. Everyone knows each other and the baristas are friendly to their regular customers but maybe only to their regular gays because except for one barista, they never acknowledge this straight girl. Oh well, I'm there for the coffee not the ambiance.
author: None o.

description:
Heaven is walking over to Peet's on Market Street, getting my coffee drink and sitting outside on one of the wooden benches maybe petting a dog as the colorful world that is Castro/Upper Market walks by.

I have enjoyed Peet's coffee ever since I was introduced to the friendly staff and open-cozy environment many years ago.

Great selection of perfectly roasted coffees and teas.

One time, a few years back, I was the Customer of the Week!!!!!

One, time, when I forgot my cel phone, I borrowed the cel of the guy/porn star sitting next to me!

Peet's, I love you.
author: Neil S.

description:
The coffee is always good at this peet's location. I am not a die hard "peetnick" or whatever you call it, but this is the most consistent quality.  The drinks come fast, and always taste good.  (It goes without saying if you want good coffee and you are in a rush, go to peet's not starbucks). 

The only bummer about this location: you can never get a seat.  The same guys are always there.  And they never leave their seats.  I am in this neighborhood a lot for work, and some days I would love to actually be able to get a seat and enjoy my coffee.
author: Dapper D.

description: I love this place. I realize that Peet's is just a chain; however, the coffee in comparison to Starbucks, is far superior. On top of that, the overall vibe is more like a small coffee shop. The people who work there are so friendly, and though I don't necessarily partake in the conversations, seeing the morning coffee groups congregate to just chat always makes a place more inviting. Plus, the pups that visit Peet's with their owners are worth the visit.
author: Leslie T.

description: overall, pretty good. i enjoy the small double latte here. but it drives me crazy that they close the bathroom with no warning, when, at least for me, urination almost always follows drinking coffee or tea.
author: Drew D.

description:
I have loved Peets since I was in high-school and used to visit the one by the Claremont Hotel.  

This is my neighborhood Peets; I buy my beans here and indulge in the occasional pumpkin scone or gingerbread.  

The staff are super friendly and funny.  I love spending my greenbacks here.  

The coffee is strong and fragrant.  It will put hair on your chest, as my dad still says.  Still not something I ever want to experience... but you can't break a parent from their little aphorisms.... can you?
author: Lm C.

description:
Coffee is great.

Service is great (this location seems to have one a number of 'best / fastest service among all Peets locations' type awards)

Maybe not a place to hang out for many hours due to lack of tables, but their coffee is always terrific.

I swear they know almost all of their customers by name too, crazy..
author: Jonathan H.

description: Decent Peet's in a good area. Great for getting that icy cold latte while shopping in the area. Yes, it was PACKED TO THE RIM with others wanting the same icy cold drinks, but the service was friendly and quick. And they have a pretty clean bathroom!
author: Jen D.

description: great place to have coffee... the staff can be little friendly some times, and some times they never say thanks when you tip them.
author: B H.

description: Shocked at the attitude given me by the manager over return of $8 worth of merchandise (glasses) for which his bean person never provided a receipt.  As a regular customer, he should have gladly returned my money rather than question my statement (glasses were clearly from his store).  Where did he get his job and attitude?  Bad example for the rest of the staff. ..... Decided to upgrade rating based on asst. manager and rest of staff.  But lose the leader, okay?
author: JH C.

description: Came here with a good friend to get coffee, you know, this place is just ok...the lines are usually longer here and the staff isn't the friendliest
author: Denny R.

description:
I still go there, but Peet's has slipped sharply among my coffee faves. Now I mainly go there to meet people at the convenient location or for the tea. Some of the staff are overworked and cold, but mostly they're great. A bigger problem is fighting your way through the dreaded morning coffee clique. They want the bench and will physically push you out of the way to get it. With their butts, so they don't have to make eye contact with the likes of you. A general sigh of relief breaks through the place when they lose critical mass and you no longer feel like something for the mean girls to walk over. It's seriously unpleasant, but also avoidable if you just skip the mornings.

Update: OK, the coffee is good and the tea selection great! Seems like there is less attitude than before. Upgrade to three stars!
author: Mike K.

description:
My dad is pretty attractive for a middle aged man. Really, he is. Salt and pepper hair, olive skin, well dressed, good taste. I accompany him here because it's the Castro, and he's attractive and straight. It's ceaselessly amusing to watch the Castro hounds give him the once, twice, thrice over and tsk-tsk that he doesn't swing their way.

Coffee's good, too. Actually, it's great. Prompt service, strong caffeinated drinks, soft banana bread, dad getting checked out. Sweet.
author: Twist H.

description: Love the drinks and the service is always great!  This is also the only Peets where i have found the ginger pumpkin muffin which is AMAZING.
author: Michelle M.

description:
JENNIFER AND FRANK ARE AWESOME!!!!!!!!!!!!!

The entire crew at Peets are awesome.......
author: Mike O.

description: This is the only place to find a cappucino with the foam whipped just the way you like it.
author: Paul H.

description:
Jesus. This place is still in what I call my "Discovery Zone." As a straight man living in the Castro for two years, I'm proud to say I've progressed from acolyte to journeyman in navigating the peculiar challenges of living straight in a gay 'hood. 

However, this coffee spot is still an unconquered bit of real estate where I fear to tread. Maybe its slogging through the gauntlet of stares  to get to the counter. Or bouncing around the awkward eddies  of humanity caught between picking up orders and accessorizing  mochas. Can't really place it, I guess. I even felt weirded out when the barista remembered my name for the first time. Perhaps this mystery is best left unsolved.
author: Veljko S.

description: Hey the coffee is really good here.  The staff friendly and  great.  No doubt.  But the crowd at the Market Street location in the Castro is equally a reason to come.  Great for people watching or meeting up with pals.  In fact, if you come at the same time everyday, you'll most likely see there are little communities here.  It's that convivial neighborhood spot you're looking for to while away the morning or afternoon. . .
author: Mark N.

description:
This Peet's is always frakkin crowded, but for good reason, I suppose. The customers and staff are generally friendly. Peet's as a whole has excellent blended drinks and coffee. I like Starbucks too, as well as a variety of SF coffee shops, but I find Peets beverages to be easier on the palate for some reason. Specifically, this Peet's location in particular is notable for the nice people inside, the pleasant foot traffic outside, and a generally sunny location.

UPDATE 8/22/07:
Oddly, I've never tried the tea in "Peet's Coffee & Tea", even though I do like tea. But this week, I've been on a tea-drinking kick at Peet's and I am absolutely amazed at the intense flavor of the teas I've tried. I've never had such bold flavor come from teas before. I would buy a canister to take home for myself but it's just such a great experience to come here in person and find a nice spot to curl up with a good book and a pot of tea. Best experience was when I took forever --- I'm very indecisive --- browsing the tea shelves and when I finally went up to the counter, the (cute) barista said, "So, where did all that thinking get you?" Attentive, friendly staff.
author: Joseph R.

description: In order to be vertical and charming each day I drop in here for my coffee-to-go. For those of you who care - the coffee (outside of Philz on 18th and 24th) is the best this city has to offer. The folks behind the counter keep the line moving, so don't worry if it's 25 people deep.
author: Chris I.

description: The most rude and disrespectful Coffee shop in town.  Unfortunately I must deliver to this shop once or twice a month as duty calls, and even that is the most horrible experience.  Everyone running around like a chicken with its head cut off and managing to be as rude as can be to everyone.  There is a lady named  who supposedly has a couple degrees yet still works here, wow so much for that gene pool WATCH OUT SHE'S A MEAN one.  Oh yah, and don't bother complaining to the manager because you'll never get ahold of them!
author: Dustin S.

description: Having grown up in Berkeley near the original Peet's Coffee, it always feels like going home when I stop by this shop. It is a wonderful alternative to Starbears on 18th, with a great selection of coffees and teas to take home and cool baked goods to go along with a nice tea. Love the benches outside, though I wish there were more seating inside.
author: Eric P.

description:
i really like -
the doggies, and
arabian mocha sanani. 

this peet's always has a gorgeous pup or a few out front...sigh, i always get my fill of coffee and puppy love...
author: Holly F.

description: Great service and great coffee... got myself a raspberry mocha and it tasted good. :)
author: Sheila L.
